work Millimeter-scale spherical alumina used as the support of Pt catalyst for isobutane dehydrogenation was prepared by alginate assisted sol-gel method, and then hydrothermal treated in 0.5 M HNO3 to improve its porous structure and surface properties. The effects of acid etching time on the composition, structure, surface acidity, redox property, catalytic dehydrogenation performance and carbon deposition of catalyst were investigated by ICP-OES, SEM, TEM, XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, 27Al MAS NMR spectra, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, isobutene transient response experiment and TGA. The results show that the acid treatment can effectively remove zinc species and partial aluminum from the surface of alumina beads, which can create defect sites and increase the specific surface area of alumina, thus improving the dispersion of Pt particles. In addition, acid etching significantly increases the acidity of alumina and enhances the interaction between Pt particles and alumina through the formation of defect sites. The Pt/Al2O3-NA-3 possesses the smallest size of Pt particles, the strongest Pt-alumina interaction, maximum number of acid sites and the highest isobutene yield of 33% even after 270 min reaction. Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Acid etching Hydrothermal Spherical alumina beads Pt catalyst Isobutane dehydrogenation Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Isobutylene is an important basic chemical raw material, which is widely used to produce a variety of high value-added industrial chemical products [1–3]. With the increasing demand of isobutene in the world, the fossil fuel resources consumed in the production of isobutene increase sharply. At the same time, shale gas and natural gas exploration technologies have been continuously improved in recent years, and their output has greatly increased [4]. These factors promote the catalytic dehydrogenation of isobutane to become an effective alternative technology for the production of isobutene [5, 6]. At present, Pt/Al2O3 catalyst is commonly used in dehydrogenation reaction because of their excellent activity, stability and environmental friendliness [7–9]. However, traditional Al2O3 support also has some problems, such as poor dispersion of Pt particles and inappropriate proportion of acid sites, which lead to the sintering and coking of Pt based catalysts in the reaction process [10–13]. Therefore, the development of modified Al2O3 support has attracted extensive attention in the dehydrogenation process [14–21]. The addition of Si, Ti oxides [14, 15], the formation of penta-coordinated Al3+ [16, 17], the adjustment of morphology and pore size [18–20], and the surface loading of hydrotalcite [21, 22]were introduced into the modification of alumina support. Jiang et al. introduced TiO2 into Al2O3 to increase the acidity of the supports and the electron density of Pt, thereby reducing the adsorption of the reaction product propylene [15]. Lu et al. synthesized Al2O3 nanosheets rich in five-coordinated aluminum atoms that was exceptionally able of dispersing and stabilizing Pt [17]. Zhao et al. prepared a carambola-like Al2O3 that facilitated mass transfer [19]. In our previous work, Al2O3 beads with various pore sizes were synthesized by combining ammonium alginate assisted sol-gel and emulsion template methods [20]. Mg-Al hydrotalcite/γ-Al2O3 balls were produced by the in-situ growth of Mg-Al hydrotalcite and used as the support precursors of Pt-based catalysts [21]. The formation of Mg-Al-O mixed oxide nanosheets on the surface of Al2O3 balls can significantly increase the specific surface area, decrease the strong acid site amount of alumina and improve the dispersion of Pt particles. Acid etching is also an effective way to modify support materials, which can increase the surface area by the generation of porous structure, enhance the dispersion of active metal by the formation of defect sites, and adjust the acidic strength and acidic site amount by the removal of some metal ions. Fan et al. synthesized SAPO-18 molecular sieve with hierarchical pore structure by etching SAPO-18 molecular sieves with hydrochloric acid, which exhibited good catalytic performance in the liquid-phase benzylation of benzene and benzyl alcohol [23]. Liu et al. prepared SAPO-34 zeolite with butterfly-shaped hierarchical pores by etching SAPO-34 with solid oxalic acid and its weak acid content was increased, thereby prolonging its life in methanol-to-olefin (MTO) reaction [24]. Meanwhile, acid etching was used to control the pore size and pore shape of porous anodic aluminum oxide (AAO) to synthesize different nanostructures [25–27]. However, there are few reports on the application of acid etching for modification of alumina supports. In the present work, spherical alumina beads were prepared by using alginate (ALG) assisted sol-gel method as reported in our previous work [20, 21] and modified by acid etching for the first time. Ammonium alginate droplets chelates with multivalent metal ions to form spherical gel beads. Zn ions were introduced during the synthesis of spherical alumina beads and then removed partially by the acid etching process. This novel preparation method is favor for the increase of surface area, the formation of cation vacancies and the adjustment of acid strength, which can promote the dispersion of active components and improve the performance of Pt/Al2O3 catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Pseudo-boehmite (PB) was synthesized by double aluminum method. Ammonium alginate (ALG) was purchased from Mingyue Seaweed Group (Shandong, China). Zn(NO3)2, and HNO3 were purchased from Jiangtian Chemical Technology Co., Ltd. H2PtCl6, and HAC were purchased from kemio Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Tianjin, China). All chemical reagents used in this study are analytically pure and have not been further purified. Deionized water was used in all experiments. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Preparation of acid etched alumina beads The preparation process is shown in Fig. 1 , which includes the production of spherical alumina beads by ALG assisted sol-gel method and the acid etching of γ-Al2O3 support with hydrothermal treatment. PB powder, ALG solution and deionized water were mixed in a certain proportion, and the homogeneous PB-ALG suspension was prepared by high-speed mixing with homogenizer. The suspension of PB-ALG was dripped into a certain concentration of Zn (NO3) 2 solution and the spherical gel beads were formed rapidly by the chelation of ammonium alginate with Zn ions. After being soaked in Zn (NO3) 2 solution for 15 min, the spherical gel beads were filtered out and cleaned with deionized water, followed by soaking in a certain concentration of acetic acid for 15 min. The wet spherical gel beads were then dried at 65℃ for 12 h and calcined at 650℃ for 4 h to obtain Al2O3 beads. The Al2O3 beads were further treated in an autoclave at 60℃ with 0.5 M HNO3 solution (5 mL HNO3 solution/1 g spherical alumina). After hydrothermal treatment, the spherical alumina beads were washed with deionized water, dried at 120℃ for 12 h and calcined at 650℃ for 4 h. By changing the hydrothermal treatment time (1, 3, 5 and 7 h), four spherical alumina supports with acid etching were obtained, and marked as Al2O3-NA-x, where x was the hydrothermal time. 2.2.2 The preparation of Pt/Al2O3-NA-x catalyst The Pt/Al2O3 -NA-x catalyst was prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method. Al2O3-NA-x beads were dipped in the H2PtCl6 solution for 12 h, dried at 100℃ for 12 h, and calcined at 450℃ for 4 h. The mass fraction of Pt in the catalyst was 0.5 wt%. 2.3 Characterization of alumina beads and catalyst The strength of alumina beads was measured with particle strength tester (YHKC-2A, China). The number of measured beads was more than 30 and the average of beads strength with N/bead was taken. Varian's VISTA-MPX inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) was used to determine the content of ZnO in the samples and the concentration of Zn2+and Al3+ions in the etching solution. For the former test, a certain amount of spherical alumina beads was ground into powder, heated and stirred to dissolve in a small amount of aqua regia, and then diluted with an appropriate amount of deionized water. The crystal phase analysis of the sample was determined by an X-ray diffractometer (D8-Focus, Cu Kα, 40 KV, 40 mA) made by Bruker, Germany, with a scanning range of 2θ=20°∼80°, and a scanning speed of 8°/min. The specific surface area and the textural structure data were measured by low temperature N2 adsorption-desorption instrument (Quanachrome Autosorb Gas Sorption System, USA), and were determined by the multipoint BET method and BJH method. The SEM image was taken with a Regulus-8100 field emission scanning electron microscope from Hitachi, Japan. The TEM image was taken with a JEM-F200 field emission transmission electron microscope from JEOL. Before the TEM test, a certain amount of catalyst was placed in a tubular furnace, and the catalyst was reduced for 2 h at 590℃ at the flow rate of H2 20 ml/min. After grinding the reduced catalyst, the catalyst was dispersed in anhydrous ethanol for 30 min, and then the suspension was dropped onto the ultra-thin carbon support film. 27Al MAS NMR spectra was recorded using the JEOL JNM ECZ600R spectrometer. NH3-TPD was used to analyze the acidic sites of the samples. 0.1 g of sample and 0.9 g of quartz sand were mixed thoroughly. The sample was heated to 550 °C at 10 °C/min in 5% N2 and held for 30 min, then cooled to 50 °C. Then, 500 ppm of NH3/N2 was passed through the catalyst samples for NH3 adsorption until the adsorption reached saturation. The weakly adsorbed NH3 on the catalyst surface was purged with N2. Finally, the sample was heated from 50 °C to 550 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min, and the change of outlet NH3 concentration with temperature was recorded in real time by infrared spectrometer. Temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was operated on the fully automatic multipurpose adsorption instrument (TP-5080E, China). 80 mg catalyst sample was placed in a quartz reactor and then heated from room temperature to 400 °C (10 °C /min) in a high-purity He atmosphere for 30 min. Then the sample was cooled down to room temperature, and the gas was switched to 5% H2/ N2 mixture gas at a flow rate of 30 ml/min. The sample was heated to 800 °C at a rate of 8 °C /min, and the thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used for on-line detection. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out with TGA/DSC 3+ thermal analyzer of Mettler, Switzerland. The spent catalysts were heated to 800℃ at the air flow rate of 100 ml/min, and the heating rate was 10 ℃/min. 2.4 Catalytic activity test The evaluation experiment of catalytic dehydrogenation of isobutane was carried out in a fixed bed reactor. 500 mg of catalyst was filled in the tubular reactor according to the structure of "quartz cotton-catalyst-quartz cotton", and then the reactor was placed in the heating furnace. The catalyst was reduced with H2 at 590 ℃ for 2 h. Then the gas was switched to the mixture of isobutane and hydrogen, the gas flow rate was 20 mL/min (H2 / C4H10 = 1:1), the reaction time was 5 h at 590℃, and the detection time was every 30 min. The tail gas was detected online by SP2100 gas chromatography. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology and structure of samples Fig. 1 shows the optical photos of Al2O3 and Al2O3-NA-x with 2–3 mm diameter, sphericity greater than 90% and smooth surface. It is indicated that the appearance of Al2O3-NA-x sample is hardly changed after the acid treatment. However, as shown in Table 1 , the strength of sample decreases obviously with the extension of acid treatment time. This may be due to the fact that the dissolution of partial alumina destroys the framework structure of spherical alumina beads, leading to a decrease in the strength of sample. It is worth noting that Al2O3-NA-7 with crushing strength of 25 N/bead could meet the requirement in general industrial application. The content of ZnO in the sample was determined by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry. It can be seen from Table 1 that the content of ZnO decreases significantly after acid treatment of alumina beads. With the increase of acid treatment time, the content of ZnO gradually decreases. After acid treatment for 3 h, the content of ZnO in the support is stable at about 1 wt.%. It is probably owing to the formation of Zn-Al composite oxides that are difficult to be dissolved in 0.5 M HNO3 solution or the wrapping of alumina to hinder the contact between ZnO and acid. The removal of Zn species from Al2O3 surface by acid etching is helpful to obtain rough alumina surface with defects. Additionally, the concentration of Zn2+and Al3+in the acid etching solution was also determined by ICP. As the time of acid treatment increases, the concentration of Zn2+ in the etching solution raises, which is corresponding to the decrease in the amount of ZnO within alumina beads. At the same time, the concentration of Al3+in the acid etching solution gradually increases, indicating that aluminum oxide is partially dissolved in the etching process. The SEM images of alumina beads under different acid treatment times are shown in Fig. 2 . The alumina beads without acid treatment have fluffy tree branches structure with relatively smooth surfaces (Fig. 2(a)). After acid treatment for 1 h (Fig. 2(b)), the morphology of sample has no obvious change. When the acid treatment time is extended to 3 h (Fig. 2(c)), the porous structure becomes denser and smaller, a large number of coarse villi, small fragments and flocs appear. Continue to increase the acid treatment time, the number of small pores and fragments increases (Fig. 2 (d-e)). It is demonstrated that acid etching can significantly affect the micromorphology and the pore structure of alumina beads. At the same time, the skeleton of alumina beads is eroded significantly by long time acid etching, thus weakening obviously the strength of the alumina beads. In order to further clarify the effect of acid etching on removal of metal ions from alumina beads, the samples were characterized by transmission electron microscopy. It can be seen from Fig. 3 (a), (d) and (g) that the black area is significantly decreased with the extension of acid treatment time, indicating that the lamellar structures of alumina are significantly thinner by acid etching. At the same time, the number of red dots in EDX element mapping images of alumina with acid etching is less than that of alumina without acid treatment, which proves that the Zn species are removed after acid treatment. The lattice spacing of about 0.2 nm as shown in Fig. 3(c), (f) and (i) belongs to the (111) crystal planes of alumina, corresponding to the diffraction peaks at 46.0° of XRD patterns (Fig. 4 ). Due to the presence of ZnO, the region of interlaced stripes as marked with a green circle in Fig. 3(c) is observed. After acid treatment of alumina beads, the region with lighter color as marked with yellow circles in Fig. 3 appear, and abundant defects are generated in Fig. 3(f) and (i), which are mainly caused by the removal of Al and Zn species. Defect sites on the surface of alumina beads by acid corrosion are helpful for the dispersion of Pt particles and improve the catalytic activity. The XRD patterns of Pt/Al2O3 and Pt/Al2O3-NA-x catalysts are shown in Fig. 4. All catalysts display the characteristic diffraction peaks of γ-Al2O3 at 2θ=36.8°, 46.0° and 66.9° (JCPDS No.49–0134), showing that the crystal phase is not destroyed during the acid etching. However, the intensity of the diffraction peak of γ-Al2O3 decreases slightly as the acid treatment time increases. For the sample with 7 h acid treatment time, the diffraction peak intensity at 66.9° is decreased from I0 to 0.73I0, which may be due to the dissolution of partial alumina. Specific surface areas, pore volumes and average pore diameters of the catalysts are summarized in Table 2 . Compared with the alumina beads without acid etching, the acid treatment increases the specific surface area and the pore volume of alumina beads, but reduces the average pore size within a certain etching time (1–5 h). It is shown that acid etching produces small pores. However, when the etching time reaches 7 h, the excessive acid treatment leads to the collapse of small pores to form large pores, which decreases the specific surface area and the pore volume. Fig. 5 . shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of the catalysts. Obviously, all samples exhibit type IV N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms with the hysteresis loop of type H3(Fig. 5(a)), indicating the mesoporous structure of the catalysts. The pore size distribution curves in Fig. 5(b) show that all samples possess the similar pore distribution. The dark field TEM photographs and the size distribution of Pt particles of catalysts are presented in Fig. 6 . The distribution of Pt particles for Pt/Al2O3 catalyst is uneven with some larger particles (Fig. 6(a)), and the average Pt particle size reaches 1.32 nm. Pt/Al2O3-NA-3 and Pt/Al2O3-NA-7 catalysts present smaller Pt particle sizes (Fig. 6(b), (c)), and the average particle sizes of Pt particles is 0.89 nm and 0.95 nm respectively, illustrating the obvious improvement of Pt dispersion due to the acid treatment of alumina. According to the analysis results from BET, SEM and TEM tests, it can be seen that the acid treatment of alumina beads can effectively remove partial Zn and Al species, leading to the increase of the specific surface area and formation of more defects on the surface, which can help to fix the Pt particles and enhance the anti-sintering ability of catalysts [28]. Furthermore, the average size of Pt particles in Pt/Al2O3-NA-3 is smaller than that in Pt/Al2O3-NA-7 because the specific surface area of former is larger than that of latter. 3.2 Surface acidity of sample In order to study the effect of acid etching on the surface acidity of alumina beads, 27Al MAS NMR spectra of the samples before and after acid etching were carried out. As shown in Fig. 7 , two peaks at 14 and 71 ppm were detected, which could be ascribed to Al3+ ions in octahedral (AlⅥ) and tetrahedral (AlⅣ) coordination respectively [17], confirming the existence of γ-Al2O3 [29]. It is worth noting that the ratio of AlⅥ/AlⅣ for Al2O3-NA-3 is reduced to 2.02 (66.92%/33.08%) from 2.22 (68.94%/31.06%) for Al2O3. This phenomenon can be explained from the coordination/dissolution mechanism during acid etching [30]. Octahedral coordination is more easily dissolved by nitric acid, leading to a decrease in the ratio of AlⅥ/AlⅣ. It was reported that octahedral Al3+ is considered as weak acid sites, and tetrahedral Al3+ belongs to strong acid sites [31]. Therefore, acid treatment should increase the acid strength of alumina supports. Fig. 8 shows the NH3-TPD curves of the Pt/Al2O3 and Pt/Al2O3-NA-x catalysts, and the NH3 desorption amount of different samples are listed in Table 3 . The NH3 desorption temperature represents the acid strength of the active sites on the catalyst surface, and the integral area of the desorption curve reflects the amount of acid sites. As shown in Fig. 8, the peak around 110 °C (peak Ⅰ) is ascribed to the physical desorption of Al2O3, while the peaks at about 210 °C (peak Ⅱ), 305 °C (peak Ⅲ), and 380 °C (peak Ⅳ) belong to weak acid, medium strong acid and strong acid sites, respectively [20]. It can be seen from Fig. 8 and Table 3 that the NH3 desorption amount of the catalysts with supports by acid treatment is significantly increased, which indicates that acid etching can enhance the acid site concentration of the catalysts due to the removal of ZnO located at the surface site and the increase of surface area. When the acid treatment time reach to 3 h, Pt/Al2O3-NA-3 has the maximum amount of acid sites. Continue to increase the acid treatment time, the acid amount of the catalyst decreases slightly, which may be caused by excessive aluminum ion dissolution. At the same time, the proportion of medium strong acid and strong acid increases significantly with the increase of treatment time, which is consistent with the results from 27Al MAS NMR spectra. 3.3 Redox properties of catalysts The redox performance of different catalysts were investigated by H2-TPR (Fig. 9 ). All catalysts have hydrogen reduction peaks in the range of 200∼300℃, which can be ascribed to the reduction peak of PtOx [32]. After acid treatment of alumina beads, the reduction peak of PtOx moves towards high temperature. This indicates that the defect sites produced by acid etching enhance the interaction between alumina and PtOx. Pt/Al2O3-NA-3 has the highest reduction peak temperature, which shows the strongest Pt-alumina interaction. It is worth noting that the acid etching catalyst has a relatively large reduction peak area, which may be caused by the more dispersed and smaller Pt particles supported on the acid etching catalyst. The largest reduction peak area of Pt/Al2O3-NA-3 implies the smallest Pt particles, which is consistent with the analysis result from TEM images of catalyst. In addition, all the catalysts also have a reduction peak near 590 ℃, which can be assigned to the surface reduction of ZnO species [33]. As reported in the literatures, zinc oxides on the surface of the support can be reduced by H2 at high temperatures [34, 35]. 3.4 Catalytic performance Fig. 10 shows the catalytic performance of Pt/Al2O3 and Pt/Al2O3-NA-x catalysts for isobutane dehydrogenation. The Pt/Al2O3-NA-x catalysts exhibit higher catalytic activity than Pt/Al2O3 catalyst. It is indicated that acid treatment of alumina beads could improve the activity of the catalyst. The isobutane conversion of Pt/Al2O3-NA-x catalyst first increases and then decreases with the increase of acid treatment time, and Pt/Al2O3-NA-3 catalyst possesses the highest isobutane conversion of 38.29% even after 270 min reaction (Fig. 10(a)). A short time of acid treatment (1–3 h) for alumina beads promotes the isobutene selectivity of catalysts, while a long time of acid treatment for supports (5–7 h) depresses them (Fig. 10(b)). The Pt/Al2O3-NA-3 catalyst still maintains the highest isobutene yield of 33% even after 270 min reaction. Many studies show that the weak acid and medium strong acid centers are the active center of catalytic dehydrogenation reaction, and the strong acid centers are the centers of cracking, isomerization and carbon deposition [6, 36-38]. It can be seen from Table 3 that the total percentage of weak acid and medium strong acid for Pt/Al2O3, Pt/Al2O3-NA-1, Pt/Al2O3-NA-3, Pt/Al2O3-NA-5 and Pt/Al2O3-NA-7 are 57.1%, 63.2%, 60.5%, 59.0% and 58.5%, respectively. The isobutene selectivity is the highest for Pt/Al2O3-NA-1 due to its large percentage of weak acid and medium strong acid sites. The higher catalytic activity for Pt/Al2O3-NA-3 is mainly attributed to the larger specific surface area of the support, smaller Pt particle size, suitable surface acid strength, the largest amount of surface acid sites, and strongest Pt-alumina interaction of catalyst. The combination of various factors lead to the highest isobutane conversion and maximum isobutene yield by Pt/Al2O3-NA-3 . 3.5 TG test of catalysts The carbon deposition of spent catalysts was quantitatively investigated by TG, and the mass loss diagram is shown in Fig. 11 . The mass loss below 320℃ is mainly attributed to the removal of physically adsorbed water, chemically bound water and organics on the spent catalyst [15, 39]. The weight loss centered at about 460℃ is attributed to the carbon combustion of the spent catalyst. Fig. 11 shows that the amount of carbon deposits was 5.30%, 6.12%, 6.84%, 6.37%, and 5.18% for Pt/Al2O3, Pt/Al2O3-NA-1, Pt/Al2O3-NA-3, Pt/Al2O3-NA-5 and Pt/Al2O3-NA-7 catalysts, respectively. This result is related to the amount of strong acid on the catalyst surface and the defect sites on the support surface. According to the results from NH3-TPD of catalysts(Table 3), the amount of strong acid for Pt/Al2O3, Pt/Al2O3-NA-1, Pt/Al2O3-NA-3, Pt/Al2O3-NA-5 and Pt/Al2O3-NA-7 are 0.0231 mmol/g, 0.0309 mmol/g, 0.0478 mmol/g, 0.0455 mmol/g and 0.0445 mmol/g respectively (Expressed by the desorbed NH3 amount), and the change trend of acid amount is consistent with carbon deposition amount on catalysts with different etching time. In addition, although the amount of strong acid of Pt/Al2O3-NA-7 is higher than that of Pt/Al2O3, the carbon deposition of the former is smaller than that of the latter. This is mainly attributed to the fact that the defect sites produced after acid etching enhance the interaction between Pt particles and supports, and promote the dispersion of Pt particles, thus improving the anti-coking ability of catalyst. 4 Conclusions The effect of acid etching on Pt-based catalysts for isobutane dehydrogenation was investigated in this paper. The Al and Zn species on the surface of alumina are removed by acid treatment, resulting in the formation of defect sites on the surface of supports and the increase in the specific surface area and the pore volume of the alumina beads, which are conducive to the dispersion of Pt particles. Compared with the alumina support without acid etching, acid etching increases the acid sites number, the acid strength of alumina beads and the interaction between the support and the Pt particles. However, long-term acid etching will lead to the decrease of acid content on the catalyst surface due to the dissolution of Al species. The high isobutene selectivity for Pt/Al2O3-NA-1 is mainly attributed to its large percentage of weak acid and medium strong acid sites. The Pt/Al2O3-NA-3 catalyst presents the highest isobutene yield of 33% even after 270 min reaction due to the larger specific surface area of the support, smaller Pt particle size, suitable surface acid strength, the largest amount of surface acid sites, and the strongest Pt-alumina interaction of catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Millimeter-scale spherical alumina used as the support of Pt catalyst for isobutane dehydrogenation was prepared by alginate assisted sol-gel method, and then hydrothermal treated in 0.5 M HNO3 to improve its porous structure and surface properties. The effects of acid etching time on the composition, structure, surface acidity, redox property, catalytic dehydrogenation performance and carbon deposition of catalyst were investigated by ICP-OES, SEM, TEM, XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, 27Al MAS NMR spectra, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, isobutene transient response experiment and TGA. The results show that the acid treatment can effectively remove zinc species and partial aluminum from the surface of alumina beads, which can create defect sites and increase the specific surface area of alumina, thus improving the dispersion of Pt particles. In addition, acid etching significantly increases the acidity of alumina and enhances the interaction between Pt particles and alumina through the formation of defect sites. The Pt/Al2O3-NA-3 possesses the smallest size of Pt particles, the strongest Pt-alumina interaction, maximum number of acid sites and the highest isobutene yield of 33% even after 270 min reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrothermal acid etching of alumina beads and its effect on isobutane dehydrogenation performance over Pt/γ-Al2O3 catalyst
